From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

Jason T.,

Many of us on this list are familiar with (if not currently practicing) XP
which encapsulates what you are talking about here, test-first design.
However, we are not always fortunate enough to be writing new code where we
can write the tests first.  Many people are writing tests for code that
pre-exists in a (at least mostly) concrete design.  The tests help us to
track down and fix bugs, refactor mercilessly, and sometimes even *change*
the cast-in-stone design.

-Jason R.

    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Jason Tryon [mailto:jtryon@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 8:44 PM
    > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    > Subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
    > 
    > 
    > My premise is that the tests are the design, not simply 
    > related thereto.  We
    > have a list of possible results of creating an order.  
    > These possible
    > outcomes determine the things we have to test.  In 
    > creating the tests, we
    > create the design.  It then becomes the tests that drive 
    > the design rather
    > than being a trailing afterthought to determine whether 
    > we anwered the
    > requirements.
    > 
    > Conventional Methodology:
    > 
    >        Requirements ----> Design ----> Construction ----> 
    > Testing -- -->
    > Delivery
    >                             ^                             
    >           |
    >                             |-----------<  Revision of 
    > Design <-----|
    > 
    > 
    > Suggested Methodology :
    > 
    >        Request ----> Tests ----> Design ----> 
    > Construction -- --> Delivery
    >                        ^                                     |
    >                        |---------< Revision of Tests <-------|
    > 
    > By devising the tests before construction, a couple of 
    > things are gained.
    > First, the request, tests and designs are closer together 
    > in the process.
    > This improves communication and the reliability of the 
    > design.  Second, the
    > tests drive the development process instead of a logical 
    > design improving
    > both the quality of the design and the answer the 
    > solution provides to the
    > original request.
    > 
    > Regards,
    > 
    > Jason Tryon
    > 
    > P.S.  It's pronounced Try - on ... like to try on a hat.  :)
    > 
    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Shane Duan [mailto:sduan@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 11:55 AM
    > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    > Subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
    > 
    > 
    > I would agree and also I would like to bring up a 
    > couter-example to Tyron's.
    > 
    > IMHO, a unit test should be closely related to the design 
    > of the class.
    > Tyron's
    > exmple seems more like a black box test rather than a 
    > white box one.  And a
    > unit
    > test should be a white-box test.
    > 
    > So the example should be modified as the following:
    > 
    > If we are talking about an Order class, a call 
    > getStatus() to another layer
    > (the
    > class should be known) with specified ProductID might 
    > return different
    > status,
    > PENDING (onhand and
    > not committed), COMMITTED(on hand but committed), 
    > IMMINENT(on order or
    > imminent
    > arrival), PROTRACTED (protracted arrival), 
    > OUT_OF_STOCK(out of stock at the
    > supplier undetermined), UNAVAILABLE.  Depending on the 
    > return status of the
    > product ID, a call to Order.create() method on a Order 
    > class might throw
    > create
    > an Order instance with PENDING status, a 
    > ProductUnavailableException, etc.
    > 
    > The point I am trying to make here is that because you 
    > know about the class
    > implementation, a unit is now finer grained in UT.  The 
    > language we are
    > speaking
    > in UT is programming-like rather than business like in AT.
    > 
    > Jason Rogers wrote:
    > 
    > >
    > >     > I would like to hear everyones thoughts on the topic.
    > >     > Your point about AT's
    > >     > is well taken.
    > >     >
    > >     > To my way of thinking, flawed though it might be, a unit
    > >     > describes one
    > >     > scenario of one behavior.  For example, if we're talking
    > >     > about an ordering
    > >     > system, a specified product might exist in a number of
    > >     > states, onhand and
    > >     > not committed, on hand but committed, on order (imminent
    > >     > arrival), on order
    > >     > (protracted arrival), out of stock at the 
    > supplier (undetermined
    > >     > availability) or perhaps even never available again.  A
    > >     > customer wanting to
    > >     > order that product might have patterned responses for
    > >     > each of these states.
    > >     > If the task at hand is to develop a system that will
    > >     > automate the response
    > >     > to a customer placing an order for this item, each
    > >     > possible state and
    > >     > outcome combination constitutes a unit.  Each test case
    > >     > contributing its
    > >     > behavioral rules to the design.
    > >
    > > I don't know, Jason.  It seems to me that unit is, for 
    > all intensive
    > > purposes, the class to be tested.  If all of these 
    > scenarios are present
    > in
    > > that one class, then they can be tested at the "unit" 
    > level.  If the
    > > scenarios are a combination of objects and their 
    > interactions, I think the
    > > test raises to the "acceptance" level.  The thing I 
    > take issue with is
    > your
    > > use of the term 'scenarios', because it conjures up ATs 
    > in my mind, but
    > that
    > > may just be me.
    > >
    > > It all comes down to what is the best way to write unit 
    > tests.  Right?
    > > That's a heated discussion from which I have learned to 
    > stay away (for the
    > > most part).  Everyone has their style and most are very 
    > adamant about it.
    > > There are some general principles that we can all agree 
    > upon, but once
    > that
    > > is done, the proofs are more or less stylistic.
    > >
    > > Some general principles can be found at
    > > 
<http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-2000/jw-1221-junit-2.html>.  I
> don't agree with the all of the things listed there, but most of it sounds
> good and right to me.
>
> -Jason
